page.title: 18THE DOUGLAS MACMILLAN HOME
page.content: The Douglas Macmillan Home deals with patients who have cancer and need special care. The home is called a hospice which means resting place. The money raised to build the home was raised in Stoke-on-Trent. The home was built in such a position that it was not near a hospital, and would make the patients forget hospitals. The home was built in 1973 and was opened by Princess Alexandra. It was named after Douglas Macmillan who set up the fund after his father died of cancer. The staff at the home consists of a matron, 4 or 5 sisters, 4 staff nurses, 25 auxillary nurses, domestic staff, 2 cooks, drivers, 2 gardeners and 40 to 50 volunteers who help but do not get paid. Altogether there are 28 beds, but at the moment a new extension is being built for a few more beds. The Health Authority only give money for 15 beds.
